document.docAuthor: Zhang, Hao-Miao, Yang, Guo-Hui & Cai, Qing-Hua
document.docTitle: Lamelligomphus annakarlorum Zhang, Yang & Cai, 2016, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A new species of Lamelligomphus Fraser, 1922 (Odonata: Gomphidae) from southern Yunnan, China

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of Lamelligomphus Fraser, 1922 (Odonata: Gomphidae) from southern Yunnan, China

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The new taxon is named for Anna Diehl and Karl Schorr, Kaiserslautern, Germany , both of whom have enjoyed working with dragonflies for many years. Anna promoted a study of Yunnan Odonata for the first author.

Material examined. Holotype :
♂, Xishuangbanna National Nature Reserve (
21 ° 57 ’ 59 ’’N
,
101 ° 12 ’ 37 ’’E
), altitude 630 m , Menglun Town, Xishuangbanna Dai Autonomous Prefecture, Yunnan Province,
15 May 2014
, Hao-miao Zhang leg.; Paratypes :
1 ♂
, same site and collector,
30 April 2014
;
1 ♂
, 1 ♀, same site and collector,
15 May 2014
;
6 ♂
, 2 ♀, same site and collector,
16 May 2013
;
1 ♂
, same site and collector,
17 May 2013
;
1 ♂
, 1 ♀, same site and collector,
02 June 2013
;
1 ♂
, 1 ♀, same site and collector,
13 September 2013
;
1 ♂
, same site and collector,
16 September 2013
;
1 ♂
, Buguzhai Village (
21 ° 37 ’ 4 ’’N
,
101 ° 35 ’ 3 ’’E
), altitude 690 m , Mengla County, Xishuangbanna Dai Autonomous Prefecture, Yunnan Province,
29 September 2014
, Hao-miao Zhang leg.

Wings. Hyaline, venation black, base of wings tinted with dark brown. Forewings: 18 (left) and 19 (right) antenodals above Sc and 19 antenodals below Sc; 18 (left) and 16 (right) postnodals above R 1 . Hindwing: 13 antenodals above Sc, 15 antenodals below Sc; 17 postnodals above R 1 . Triangles not crossed. Median space without crossvein. Anal triangle 4 -celled. Pterostigma black, well braced, below covering 8 cells on forewings, 8 (left) and 9 (right) cells on hindwings.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–2. Habitus of
Lamelligomphus annakarlorum
sp. nov.
: (1) holotype male; (2) paratype female.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Variation in paratype males.
Yellow marking on metepimeron very variable; the majority of specimens similar in size to holotype , but in some paratype males the yellow marking on metepimeron longer and larger (
Fig. 11
). In some males dorsal stripes connect with collar stripes.

Measurements (mm). Holotype male: total length 69.0, abdomen (including anal appendages) 52.0, hind wing 42 ; Paratype males: total length 65.0–68.0, abdomen (including anal appendages) 49.0–51.0, hind wing 38.0– 41.5 . Paratype females: total length 63.0–68.0, abdomen (including anal appendages) 47.0–51.0, hind wing 42.5 – 45.0.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 3–12.
Lamelligomphus annakarlorum
sp. nov.
, details of type specimens: holotype male (3–6), paratype male (11) and paratype females (7–10, 12); (3) head in frontal view; (4) thorax in lateral view; (5) abdomen in lateral view; (6) abdomen in dorsal view; (7) head in frontal view; (8) thorax in lateral view; (9) abdomen in lateral view; (10) abdomen in dorsal view; (11) thorax in lateral view; (12) thorax in lateral view.

FIGURES 13–21. Details of
Lamelligomphus annakarlorum
sp. nov.
(holotype male 13–16, paratype female 17) and
L. camelus (Martin, 1904)
(female 18, male 19–21): (13, 19) S7–10 and anal appendages in lateral view; (14) same in dorsal view; (15, 20) vesica spermalis in lateral view; (16, 21) hamulus in lateral view; (17–18) vulvar lamina in ventral view.

FIGURES 22–23. Photos in life of
Lamelligomphus annakarlorum
sp. nov.
, paratype males. Photos by Hao-miao Zhang; (23) Xishuangbanna National Nature Reserve, Menglun Town, Xishuangbanna Dai Autonomous Prefecture, Yunnan Province, 16 May 2013; (24) same site, 13 September 2013.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. Currently known only from Xishuangbanna Dai Autonomous Prefecture in southern Yunnan province, China .

Notes on biology. The type locality is in the tropical rain forest, where the best forests can be seen all over Xishuangbanna Dai Autonomous Prefecture; at least 160 species have been found in this area (personal records by Haomiao Zhang). Most of the type specimens were collected at a long flowing montane stream within deep forest in the Xishuangbanna National Nature Reserve. This stream was about 1.5 –3.0 m wide; in the dry season (November to June) the water level was low, about 0.3 m deep. This new species prefers open sections of the stream, and males usually perched on marginal vegetation including big rocks in the stream or the sandy beach.

Males were active during the daytime from 10 :00– 17 :00 hours. Most of the time they perched, but sometimes they hovered close to the water's surface. Males fight for territory. Females were rarely seen, but they usually appeared in the semi-shady or shady part where they laid eggs while hovering.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 24–25. Photos in life of
Lamelligomphus annakarlorum
sp. nov.
, paratype females. Photos by Hao-miao Zhang; (24) Xishuangbanna National Nature Reserve, Menglun Town, Xishuangbanna Dai Autonomous Prefecture, Yunnan Province, 16 May 2013; (25) same site, 13 September 2013.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Differential diagnosis. This new species is most similar to
Lamelligomphus camelus
, especially by the paired hump-shaped tubercles on dorsal part of S 8 (
Figs. 13 –14, 19
). We were unable to find any differences in male anal appendages and only small differences in the secondary genitalia; the paired flagellum of
L. camelus
is longer ( Fig.

20 ), and the hamulus of
L. camelus
is stouter (
Fig. 21
). The shape of the female vulvar lamina is approximately triangular in
L. annakarlorum
(
Fig. 17
) but not so angled in
L. camelus
(
Fig. 18
). Most members of this genus have a similar male vesica and anal appendage morphology. Body maculation plays an important role in separating these two species. More information about
L. camelus
is provided below, based on studying comprehensive specimen material throughout its range, especially the variation of body maculation, and we can see clearly the differences between the two species. A combination of summarized characters for separating
L. annakarlorum
from
L. camelus
are shown in
Table 1
.
